When iterating from 2<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math>$2$ to n<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>$n$, if we reach a number that has deg<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>g</mi></math>$deg$ equal to 0<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn></math>$0$, then it is a prime and its deg<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>g</mi></math>$deg$ is 1<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math>$1$.
      • During the sieve of Eratosthenes, we will iterate i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>i</mi></math>$i$ from 2<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math>$2$ to n<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>$n$. When processing a prime number we go through all of its multiples and increase their deg[]<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></math>$deg[]$. If one of these multiples is multiple of the square of i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>i</mi></math>$i$, then we can put good<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>g</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>d</mi></math>$good$ as false.

    2. Second, we need to calculate the answer for all i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>i</mi></math>$i$ from 2<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math>$2$ to n<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>$n$, i.e., the array cnt[]<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>c</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></math>$cnt[]$ the number of integers not coprime with i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>i</mi></math>$i$.

      • To do this, remember how the formula of inclusion-exclusion works actually here we implement the same concept, but with inverted logic: we iterate over a component (a product of primes from the factorization) and add or subtract its term on the formula of inclusion-exclusion of each of its multiples.
      • So, let's say we are processing a number i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>i</mi></math>$i$ such that good[i]=true<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>g</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>t</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>u</mi><mi>e</mi></math>$good[i] = true$, i.e., it is involved in the formula of inclusion-exclusion. Iterate through all numbers that are multiples of i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>i</mi></math>$i$, and either add or subtract N/i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo fence="false" stretchy="false"></mo><mi>N</mi><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mo>/</mo></mrow><mi>i</mi><mo fence="false" stretchy="false"></mo></math>$\lfloor N/i \rfloor$ from their cnt[]<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>c</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></math>$cnt[]$ (the signal depends on deg[i]<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></math>$deg[i]$: if deg[i]<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></math>$deg[i]$ is odd, then we must add, otherwise subtract).

    Here's a C++ implementation:

    int n;
bool good[MAXN];
int deg[MAXN], cnt[MAXN];

long long solve() {
    memset (good, 1, sizeof good);
    memset (deg, 0, sizeof deg);
    memset (cnt, 0, sizeof cnt);

    long long ans_bad = 0;
    for (int i=2; i<=n; ++i) {
        if (good[i]) {
            if (deg[i] == 0)  deg[i] = 1;
            for (int j=1; i*j<=n; ++j) {
                if (j > 1 && deg[i] == 1)
                    if (j % i == 0)
                        good[i*j] = false;
                    else
                        ++deg[i*j];
                cnt[i*j] += (n / i) * (deg[i]%2==1 ? +1 : -1);
            }
        }
        ans_bad += (cnt[i] - 1) * 1ll * (n-1 - cnt[i]);
    }

    return (n-1) * 1ll * (n-2) * (n-3) / 6 - ans_bad / 2;
}

    The asymptotics of our solution is O(nlogn)<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mi>log</mi><mo data-mjx-texclass="NONE"></mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>$O(n \log n)$, as for almost every number up to n<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>$n$ we make n/i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mo>/</mo></mrow><mi>i</mi></math>$n/i$ iterations on the nested loop.

    The number of permutations without fixed points (derangements)

    Prove that the number of permutations of length n<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>$n$ without fixed points (i.e. no number i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>i</mi></math>$i$ is in position i<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>i</mi></math>$i$ - also called a derangement) is equal to the following number:

    n!(n1)(n1)!+(n2)(n2)!(n3)(n3)!+(nn)(nn)!<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><mi>n</mi><mo>!</mo><mo></mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>1</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo>+</mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo></mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>3</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo>+</mo><mo></mo><mo></mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mi>n</mi></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo></math>$$n! - \binom{n}{1} \cdot (n-1)! + \binom{n}{2} \cdot (n-2)! - \binom{n}{3} \cdot (n-3)! + \cdots \pm \binom{n}{n} \cdot (n-n)! $$

    and approximately equal to:

    n!e<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>!</mo></mrow><mi>e</mi></mfrac></math>$$ \frac{ n! }{ e } $$

    (if you round this expression to the nearest whole number you get exactly the number of permutations without fixed points)

    Denote by Ak<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>$A_k$ the set of permutations of length n<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>$n$ with a fixed point at position k<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi></math>$k$ (1kn<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo></mo><mi>k</mi><mo></mo><mi>n</mi></math>$1 \le k \le n$) (i.e. element k<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi></math>$k$ is at position k<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi></math>$k$).

    We now use the formula of inclusion-exclusion to count the number of permutations with at least one fixed point. For this we need to learn to count sizes of an intersection of sets Ai<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi></msub></math>$A_i$, as follows:

    |Ap|=(n1)! ,|ApAq|=(n2)! ,|ApAqAr|=(n3)! ,,<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" columnalign="right center left" columnspacing="0em 0.278em" rowspacing="3pt"><mtr><mtd><mrow data-mjx-texclass="INNER"><mo data-mjx-texclass="OPEN">|</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE">|</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mi></mi><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd><mi></mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mo>,</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow data-mjx-texclass="INNER"><mo data-mjx-texclass="OPEN">|</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo></mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>q</mi></msub><mo data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE">|</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mi></mi><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd><mi></mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mo>,</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow data-mjx-texclass="INNER"><mo data-mjx-texclass="OPEN">|</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo></mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>q</mi></msub><mo></mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>r</mi></msub><mo data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE">|</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mi></mi><mo>=</mo></mtd><mtd><mi></mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>3</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mo>,</mo></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mo></mo><mo>,</mo></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>$$\begin{eqnarray} \left| A_p \right| &=& (n-1)!\ , \\ \left| A_p \cap A_q \right| &=& (n-2)!\ , \\ \left| A_p \cap A_q \cap A_r \right| &=& (n-3)!\ , \\ \cdots , \end{eqnarray}$$

    because if we know that the number of fixed points is equal x<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>$x$, then we know the position of x<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>$x$ elements of the permutation, and all other (nx)<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>$(n-x)$ elements can be placed anywhere.

    Substituting this into the formula of inclusion-exclusion, and given that the number of ways to choose a subset of size x<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math>$x$ from the set of n<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>$n$ elements is equal to (nx)<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="1.2em" maxsize="1.2em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mi>x</mi></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="1.2em" maxsize="1.2em">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>$\binom{n}{x}$, we obtain a formula for the number of permutations with at least one fixed point:

    (n1)(n1)!(n2)(n2)!+(n3)(n3)!(nn)(nn)!<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>1</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo></mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo>+</mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>3</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo></mo><mo></mo><mo></mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mi>n</mi></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo></math>$$\binom{n}{1} \cdot (n-1)! - \binom{n}{2} \cdot (n-2)! + \binom{n}{3} \cdot (n-3)! - \cdots \pm \binom{n}{n} \cdot (n-n)! $$

    Then the number of permutations without fixed points is equal to:

    n!(n1)(n1)!+(n2)(n2)!(n3)(n3)!+(nn)(nn)!<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><mi>n</mi><mo>!</mo><mo></mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>1</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo>+</mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo></mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mn>3</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo><mo>+</mo><mo></mo><mo></mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mrow data-mjx-texclass="OPEN"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">(</mo></mrow><mfrac linethickness="0"><mi>n</mi><mi>n</mi></mfrac><mrow data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE"><mo minsize="2.047em" maxsize="2.047em">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo></mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo></mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>!</mo></math>$$n! - \binom{n}{1} \cdot (n-1)! + \binom{n}{2} \cdot (n-2)! - \binom{n}{3} \cdot (n-3)! + \cdots \pm \binom{n}{n} \cdot (n-n)! $$

    Simplifying this expression, we obtain exact and approximate expressions for the number of permutations without fixed points:

    n!(111!+12!13!+1n!)n!e<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><mi>n</mi><mo>!</mo><mrow data-mjx-texclass="INNER"><mo data-mjx-texclass="OPEN">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo></mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo></mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mo></mo><mo></mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>!</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo data-mjx-texclass="CLOSE">)</mo></mrow><mo></mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>!</mo></mrow><mi>e</mi></mfrac></math>$$ n! \left( 1 - \frac{1}{1!} + \frac{1}{2!} - \frac{1}{3!} + \cdots \pm \frac{1}{n!} \right ) \approx \frac{n!}{e} $$

    (because the sum in brackets are the first n+1<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>$n+1$ terms of the expansion in Taylor series e1<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow data-mjx-texclass="ORD"><mo></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>$e^{-1}$)

    It is worth noting that a similar problem can be solved this way: when you need the fixed points were not among the m<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math>$m$ first elements of permutations (and not among all, as we just solved). The formula obtained is as the given above accurate formula, but it will go up to the sum of k<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi></math>$k$, instead of n<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi></math>$n$.
